summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Richard M. Berman, formally notifying the court of Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in custody and requesting the entry of an order of nolle prosequi (dismissal of charges) due to the defendant's death prior to final conviction. The letter also states the government's commitment to victims under the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who died by suicide while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Richard M. Berman
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case United States v. Jeffrey Epstein, to whom this formal notification letter is addressed.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman

connections.description: Geoffrey S. Berman, as the U.S. Attorney, is the lead prosecutor for the government in the criminal case against defendant Jeffrey Epstein.
Judge Richard M. Berman is the presiding judicial officer over the criminal case United States v. Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner later determined the cause was hanging and the manner was suicide.

events.title: Medical Examiner's Statement
events.description: The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York issued a statement identifying Epstein's cause of death as hanging and the manner as suicide.

events.title: Government Requests Nolle Prosequi
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files this letter with the court, formally requesting dismissal of the charges (nolle prosequi) due to the defendant's death prior to final conviction.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (where Epstein died in custody)
Southern District of New York (jurisdiction of the court)
New York, New York (location of the courthouse and U.S. Attorney's Office)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died on the morning of August 10, 2019, while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.
The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner determined the cause of death was hanging and the manner was suicide.
Due to Epstein's death prior to a final conviction, the government is required to request the court dismiss the charges via an order of nolle prosequi.
The government states it has made efforts to contact all identified victims since learning of Epstein's death, in accordance with the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
The U.S. Attorney's Office publicly reaffirms its commitment to standing up for the victims who have come forward and those who have yet to do so.
